newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds close mixed, yield curve flattens.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds close mixed, yield curve flattens.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed mixed on Thursday, with the yield curve flattening slightly, as a drop in the Canadian dollar to a two-year low weighed on the short end of the curve, analysts said.

"The weakness in the short end is coming from the Canadian dollar," said Sheldon Dong, manager of fixed-income research with Midland Walwyn Capital Inc. "I'm surprised that it (the market) is ignoring the dollar completely at the long end."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.40 to C$108.60 to yield 7.260 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond rose 11/32 to yield 7.07 percent. The spread between the two bonds narrowed to 19 basis points from 22 basis points on Wednesday.
Canada's dollar ended weaker on Thursday at C$1.4005 (US$0.7140) from this morning's open around C$1.3985 (US$0.7150), after reaching a two-year low of C$1.4018 (US$0.7133) in overnight trade.

However, long bonds rallied with Treasuries, which benefited from a jump in U.S. jobless claims and a decline in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's index of business activity in the manufacturing sector.

"Today you saw a little bit of benign real sector data with the Philly Fed. So it seems like for the day at least the people in the non-Fed tighening camp won out," said Harvinder Kalirai, Canadian analyst with New York-based financial analysis firm I.D.E.A.

In new issue news, the Government of Canada said it plans to auction on April 23 a total of C$1.3 billion of bonds with a coupon of 8.0 percent and maturing on June 1, 2027. The Bank of Canada will buy a minimum of C$195 million of the issue.
In other prices, the Canadian 10-year benchmark bond rose C$0.30 to C$102.10 to yield 6.699 percent.
The U.S. bond rose 8/32 to yield 6.85 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 15 basis points from 14 basis points on Wednesday.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 3.20 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 5.29 percent.
